An increase in abrupt thaw lake permafrost carbon emissions
requires an acceleration of gross thermokarst lake area growth
rates. Such an acceleration was observed in the early Holocene
when the frequency of thermokarst-lake basal dates peaked in
association with the 1.6 ± 0.8 °C climate warming during the

Abrupt thaw impacts on 21st century emissions
of 21st-century CLM and AThaw model results brings to light
ndings. First, accounting for abrupt permafrost
thaw beneath lakes, which peaks mid-century in response to
RCP8.5 atmospheric temperature rise (Supplementary Figs 4 and
5), increases late 21st century circumpolar permafrost carbon
Supplementary Data 1). Corresponding CPCRE is increased by
265%, 68% uncertainty) over that from gradual top-
down thaw alone (Fig. 4h), which was the basis of previous PCF
. We acknowledge that the extent to which
AThaw emissions affect CPCRE depends on the land-surface
, but in all cases would result in a signi
increase. End-of-the-century weakening of the abrupt thaw lake
contribution to CPCRE occurs because strong warming in
